Introduction

Cigarette smoking is the leading cause of preventable disease, disability, and death among adults worldwide.  Smoking cessation is an evidence-based suite of behavioral support and pharmacotherapy approaches that need to be individualized to each patient.

Pathophysiology

Nicotine dependency

Problematic (chronic) tobacco use (eg, tobacco use disorder) involves complex physiological and psychosocial mechanisms:

  • Physiological (ie, dependency):  Nicotine strongly binds nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs), primarily in the mesolimbic dopamine pathway.  Tolerance (higher concentrations of nicotine needed to achieve similar levels of dopamine release) gradually develops.  Sudden nicotine cessation leads to acute withdrawal (irritability, cravings), which is the hallmark of dependency.
  • Psychosocial (ie, addiction):  Patients with longtime smoking habits may develop distorted perceptions about their smoking behavior.  For example, they may overestimate potential benefits (eg, weight control) while underestimating risks (eg, asthma flare-ups).  Habits may contribute.  For example, smoking is often linked to daily routines (eg, first cigarette with morning coffee), and oral fixation (satisfaction from the ritual of lighting up a cigarette, holding it, and exhaling smoke) can become a conditioned response to stress.

Predictors of continued smoking

Among patients trying to quit, unsuccessful smoking cessation correlates with the following factors:

  • High nicotine dependency:  Time to first cigarette (TTFC) upon waking is the single most powerful indicator of nicotine dependency.  A short TTFC (<30 min) or smoking in bed indicates greater physiological dependency.  Heavy smoking (eg, >30 cigarettes/day) is important but not as predictive as TTFC.
  • Comorbid psychiatric disorders:  Over one-third of patients who smoke have a serious concurrent psychiatric illness.  Smoking cessation is least likely to succeed in patients with schizophrenia and substance (eg, alcohol) use disorders.
  • Cohabitation with an individual who smokes (lack of social support, constant exposure to environmental smoking cues):  Cessation is typically difficult unless the entire household is committed as a team.
  • Other factors:
    • Younger onset of smoking (ie, during adolescence) is associated with a lower quitting rate, possibly due to higher expression and sensitivity of dopaminergic receptors in youth.
    • Low motivation or confidence (<7 on a 10-point scale) in ability to quit
    • Brief periods of abstinence following past cessation attempts (ie, frequent relapses).  Notably, the number of previous quit attempts is not necessarily a negative predictor (eg, patients often learn through prior experiences).

Core principles

The 5As

The universal principles of smoking cessation are summarized with the 5As (

):

  • Ask about tobacco use:  All patients should be asked about tobacco use at each clinic visit.  The screening question is constructed to have the highest sensitivity possible (eg, "Do you ever smoke cigarettes?").
  • Advise against smoking:  Patients who are currently smoking should be advised to quit immediately (eg, "Now is a great time to quit smoking.  I will help you.").  Every minute counts (eg, 5 min of advice = 5% increase in quit success rate).
  • Assess readiness to quit:  The most direct way is to ask for a firm quit date (eg, "When are you going to quit smoking?  Let me mark it on my calendar.").  For patients who do not answer right away, the urge to propose a date for them should be resisted.  Often, resolutions solidify in the period of hesitation.
  • Assist with quitting:  When a firm quit date is established, a cessation plan should be developed with the patient.  The plan typically includes individual interventions (eg, behavioral therapy plus pharmacotherapy), trigger anticipation, and external resources (eg, quit hotline).
  • Arrange follow-up:  Proactive (eg, clinical calls to patients 3 days before their planned quit date) contact is more effective than waiting for the next office visit.

Three major interventions

Based on the 5As, smoking cessation consists of 3 major interventions:

  • Motivational interviewing
  • Behavioral counseling
  • Pharmacotherapy

These interventions (used alone or together) are tailored to the patient's stage of change (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).  Motivational interviewing is traditionally viewed as the main tool for advancing from precontemplation to preparation.  However, it is relevant at all stages of change (
ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
).

Not ready to quit

The stage of being not ready to quit is also referred to as the precontemplation stage of change.  For patients in the precontemplation stage (eg, those unwilling to give a firm quit date), the goal is to help unlock their internal motivation.

Motivational interviewing

At the heart of motivational interviewing is the notion that all individuals in the precontemplation stage harbor some ambivalence about their behavior (despite not acknowledging negative consequences of their behavior).  At this stage of motivational interviewing, there are 2 goals:

  • Explore ambivalence:  The key components are open-ended questions (eg, "What are some things you like and dislike about smoking as part of your daily routine?") and reflective listening (eg, asking clarifying questions, paraphrasing).
  • Develop discrepancies:  The next phase of motivational interviewing is to help patients recognize a gap between their current smoking and deeper personal values.  This can be accomplished through provocative prompts (eg, "Tell me about a time when smoking got in the way of something important to you").

Although recommending action is premature during this stage, it is helpful to provide education on short- and long-term benefits of smoking cessation.  Some motivational nuggets are provided below:

  • Major adverse cardiovascular event (MACE)
    • One week after smoking cessation:  The risk for acute myocardial infarction and stroke begins to decrease measurably.
    • One year after smoking cessation:  The risk for MACE is reduced to 50% compared to a person who continues to smoke.
  • Cancer risk
    • One year after smoking cessation:  The risk for being diagnosed with any cancer (primarily lung) decreases measurably.
    • Ten years after smoking cessation:  The risk for dying from cancer is reduced to 50% compared to a person who continues to smoke.
  • Mortality (smoking cessation improves survival at all ages)
    • Quitting by age 30 eliminates 100% of future attributable risk and adds 11 years to the patient's life expectancy.
    • Quitting by age 50 eliminates 50% of future attributable risk and adds 7 years to the patient's life expectancy.

Certain conditions may resonate more personally with patients based on their fears and experiences (eg, friend recently diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease).

Precontemplation pharmacotherapy

For patients in the precontemplation stage, it is reasonable to offer proactive treatment with varenicline while continuing general motivational interviewing.  This strategy results in a 2-fold improvement for 1-year complete smoking cessation.  Varenicline is a partial agonist of nAChR that simultaneously activates (prevents nicotine withdrawal) and inhibits (reduces cravings) the receptor.  Patients successfully treated report becoming apathetic towards smoking ("I just kind of lost interest").  Varenicline is generally continued for 12 weeks after the last cigarette.

Ready to quit

The stage of being ready to quit is also referred to as the preparation and action stage of change and is signaled by committing to a firm quit date.  To capitalize on momentum, the quit date should be within 2 weeks from the current date.  In some cases, some patients are motivated by dates carrying special significance (eg, anniversaries, birthdays).  The goal of complete cessation (ie, zero cigarettes) should be stated explicitly (eg, "Cutting down is not enough.  You only get the benefits by quitting completely.").

Motivational interviewing

During the preparation and action phase, the 2 goals of motivational interviewing are the following:

  • Promote self-confidence:  High confidence (â‰¥7 on a 10-point scale) in one's ability to quit enhances the likelihood for success.  Confidence can be built with strategic questions to create positive bias (eg, "You mentioned that your confidence level is 6 out of 10.  Why didn't you say 4?") and nudge patients to recognize their own internal strength.
  • Enact small steps (precessation):  Prior to the quit date, it is important to enact a set of concrete changes, including:
    • Consolidating smoking paraphernalia (eg, ashtrays, lighters) to be discarded on the quit date
    • Broadcasting their quit date to social supports (eg, family, friends, colleagues)
    • Identifying and replacing triggers (eg, drink morning tea instead of coffee)
    • Rehearsing action plans during cravings (eg, chew gum and call a friend)

Advanced preparation yields better outcomes.  Ideally, patients should feel relaxed (and potentially excited) about stopping smoking on their quit date.

Combination therapy

Behavioral counseling and pharmacotherapy have synergistic effects when combined.  Compared to patients who use neither behavioral counseling nor pharmacotherapy, those who use either alone have a 40% higher likelihood of smoking cessation, and those who use both have a 170% higher likelihood of smoking cessation.

Behavioral counseling (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
) includes motivational interviewing and other forms of behavioral counseling:

  • Synchronous interaction (eg, telephone calls or telemedicine visits)
  • Asynchronous interaction (eg, secure text messaging)
  • Smartphone applications
  • Generative artificial intelligence chatbots

Pharmacotherapy (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
) includes nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), bupropion, and varenicline:

  • NRT:  A basal + bolus (eg, patch + gum) approach is recommended.  The basal component prevents nicotine withdrawal and is dosed based on average daily cigarettes (eg, 21-mg patch if >10 cigarettes/day).  The bolus component simulates plasma nicotine peaks during smoking and is dosed based on TTFC (eg, 4-mg gum if <30 min).  The bolus product type (eg, inhaler, lozenge, spray) can also combat oral fixation.
  • Bupropion:  In addition to being a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor, bupropion is also a nAChR agonist.  Its anorectic properties can reduce postcessation weight gain, and it may be a good choice for patients who smoke and have comorbid depression.
  • Varenicline:  This is the most effective single agent (vs NRT or bupropion alone).  A partial nAChR agonist, varenicline prevents withdrawal (agonist effect) and reduces cravings (antagonist effect).  Common adverse effects include insomnia and bizarre dreams, but these symptoms are mitigated by taking the second dose several hours before bedtime.  Despite a previous black box warning (reversed in 2016), varenicline can be safely used in patients with stable mood disorders.

Bupropion and varenicline are typically started a week prior to the quit date and continued for 12 weeks after the last cigarette.

Combined behavioral therapy and pharmacotherapy are recommended for most adults who smoke.  However, initial behavioral therapy alone may be appropriate for selected patients (

figure 1
) (eg, those who smoke little or occasionally, adolescents, pregnant women).

Struggling to quit

Smoking cessation is an iterative process in which relapses are common.  However, the epidemiology of cessation reveals an optimistic picture overall:

  • Of patients who attempt to quit, >50% eventually stop smoking permanently.
  • It takes an average of approximately 5 sincere quit attempts before durable cessation.
  • The prevalence of smoking is declining steadily.

Motivational interviewing

For patients who are struggling to quit (or facing a recent relapse), the 2 goals of motivational interviewing are to:

  • Reinforce partial achievements:  Forward-looking statements can reinspire hope in patients who may be feeling discouraged (eg, "Given your success in reducing your smoking so far, I believe in your goal of quitting completely").  Although progress should be praised, it is important to avoid settling for the lesser goal of partial cessation.
  • Unlink triggers:  Patients should list triggers and habits that prompt them to smoke (eg, morning coffee, stressful commute, bowel movement).  Next, they should propose alternate behaviors (eg, walking 500 steps, practicing deep breathing) that can distract from the urge to smoke.  It is helpful to reassure patients that most strong urges only last 5-10 minutes.  Focusing on the first cigarette of the day makes the challenge more manageable.  Postponing the first cigarette develops skills that immediately translate to the broader cessation effort.

Managing cessation's "side effects"

A range of bothersome symptoms (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 6
) occur after smoking cessation.  They usually resolve with supportive care and determination.  Patients should be prepared to experience:

  • Nicotine withdrawal:  Despite pharmacotherapy, some amount of dysphoria, restlessness, and cravings should be expected.
  • Weight gain:  Increased appetite postcessation leads to a 2-4 kg (5-8 lb) weight gain on average.  The benefits of smoking cessation far exceed the slight increase in BMI.
  • Productive cough:  Bronchial cilia are paralyzed by cigarette smoke.  As they reawaken, excessive mucus production and bronchospasm can occur.  These symptoms resolve after 2-4 weeks.

Summary

Cigarette smoking is the leading cause of preventable death globally.  Tobacco use disorder is a complex process involving physiological dependency (nicotine tolerance and withdrawal) as well as psychological addiction (based on habits and social structures).  A patient's inability to delay the first cigarette upon waking is the strongest predictor of dependency.  Comorbid psychiatric disorders and cohabitation with an individual who smokes also hinder cessation efforts.  The 3 key interventions for smoking cessation are:

  • Motivational interviewing
  • Behavioral counseling (eg, proactive telephone support)
  • Pharmacotherapy (eg, nicotine replacement therapy, bupropion, varenicline)

Motivational interviewing is appropriate during every stage of change but is most relevant for patients who are not ready to quit.  Combined behavioral therapy and pharmacotherapy are recommended for most patients who smoke and are ready to quit.  Relapse is common, but >50% of those attempting to quit eventually succeed.
